events.title: ui
events.description:
the entirety of abho's C3 UI Framework, right here.
not everything here needs to be learned and tampered with, but there is some stuff that's important to know.

children.text: UI states (don't adjust these directly, use the relevant functions)

children.name: uiChosenID
children.comment: the actual UI component that is focused right now

children.name: uiInputMode
children.comment: what mode does navigation adhere to - can be "default", "slider", "carousel"

children.name: uiInputDevice
children.comment: the last recorded input method - "mouse", "keyboard", or "gamepad"

children.text:
delimiter used for carousels
on default ',' but if you need to use a comma in a value you want to display, feel free to change
this is a lot of code and even with comments it's difficult to put together what everything does, so look for these pink comments for a tl;dr.

children.title: ui / init
children.description: everything to do with setting properties when something is created, you can find On Created events for most UI families here

children.text: when a UI component is created, initialize some properties

actions.text: here, I choose to record the width and height of every button by default so that I can manipulate their sizes for animations later. this isn't required and you could do anything else here.

children.text: if navigable, meaning it can be chosen and selected like a normal button

thank goodness, for some reason the bool 'navigable' is being set to false correctly when slider bars, fills, etc. are being created further below.
I don't know if this is event-order sensitive at all, but it DOES work. just be weary...

actions.text: call deactivate for this button on default

children.text: when scroll view is created
when scroll component is created
when slider bar is created

actions.text: disable the ability for this component to be chosen and selected, since it's just a slider bar
update the ticks

children.text: pick attached slider handles
pick attached slider fills
slider ticks aren't here since they are generated automatically
when slider handle is created

actions.text: update the slider value to fit

children.text: when slider fill is created

actions.text: disable the ability for this component to be chosen and selected
update this fill

children.text: when slider tick is created

actions.text: disable the ability for this component to be chosen and selected

children.text: when check box is created
run custom action relevant to current state
when carousel is created

children.title: ui / sections
children.description: a few essential functions you'll need for enabling and disabling sections, which can be thought of as a collection of UI components - you can set an object's section with the instance variable.

children.text:
you can think of sections like a collection of buttons. 

on a main menu layout alone you'll probably have multiple sections, such as...

- a 'main' section, which would include buttons with an id like mainPlay, mainSettings, mainQuit, etc.
- a 'mainPlay' section, where upon clicking the mainPlay button, new options appear such as mainPlayNewGame, mainPlayLoadGame, etc.
- a 'mainQuit' section, where clicking mainQuit takes you to mainQuitConfirm and mainQuitCancel
- even more sections like 'mainSettings', which could lead to 'mainSectionsVideo', 'mainSectionGameplay', 'mainSectionControlsKeyboardConfirmBind', who knows!

so long as it's part of the ui family, you should assign a section to it

below are some functions you should use to enable and disable sections. some examples of using these functions are...

- on start of layout, enable section "main"
- on 'mainPlay' selected, disable section "main" and enable section "mainPlay"
- on clicking 'mainPlayNewGame', maybe a transition will happen and fade to a new layout. to make sure no more buttons can be pressed, disable all sections
enable/disable a UI section - this will run a ui update

children.functionDescription: enables a section of UI components - this will run a ui update

children.text: update the UI afterwards

children.functionDescription: disables a section of UI components - this will run a ui update

children.text: update the UI afterwards

children.functionDescription: disables every UI component on the layout - runs a UI update

actions.text: set navigation mode to default, then call a ui update

children.title: ui / custom actions
children.description: custom actions are a modular way to apply visual behavior like tweening to all objects in the UI families, but also override the behavior for individual objects

children.text:
with these custom actions, you can provide a default behavior here, and override the default by creating an override custom action for the button object.

if you want a special button type on some layout to do something different from the default, you can make an override by creating a new custom action for that object, and calling the action the exact same thing.
you'll know you've done it right because it'll say 'Overridden' next to it. if it has any parameters, copy those over too.

lastly, if you wanted to do the default behavior but THEN ALSO do something custom, then you can call the family custom action as part of the overwrite to turn it into an extension.
if that didn't make sense, it's a little complicated to explain here, so see link below.

to learn more about custom actions and overriding, see here --> https://www.construct.net/en/make-games/manuals/construct-3/project-primitives/events/custom-actions
when the section this button is in gets enabled

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- make the button become brighter somehow, to show it is clickable

children.text: when the section this button is in gets disabled

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- make the button become darker somehow, to show it is unavailable

children.text: when this component gets chosen (not selected, think of it as mouseover)

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- become bigger
- change color
- slightly move

children.text: when this component gets unchosen, meaning the player chose something else

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- do the opposite of what you did in uiChoose

children.text: when this button is selected, meaning the user clicked on it or pressed the select button

DON'T use this for telling the game what happens when you click a certain button! these custom actions are used to define a general behavior for every component. instead, use a surface function call to register when a specific button ID is clicked.

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- get creative! give some major visual/audio feedback to show the player their input was registered immediately. some examples below...
- become even bigger
- particles
- select sound
- tilt
- warp effect

children.text: when this handle gets selected (different from uiSelect because you can "deselect" a slider handle)

when overriding this custom action, the conditions don't carry to your override.
these custom actions exist on the uiSliderHandle family, but we tie it to the relevant ui family object with a UID check and perform changes there to access the tween behavior and variables

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- add condition "ui -> pick instance with UID: uiSliderHandle.UID"
- call the default uiSelect action on the ui family (if appropriate)
- grow larger
- change color
- tilt
- sound effect

children.text: when this handle gets deselected (dropped, value is no longer being changed)

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- add condition "ui -> pick instance with UID: uiSliderHandle.UID"
- do the opposite of what you did in uiSliderHandleSelect

children.text: when this handle is being moved by the player, only triggers when the handle value changes

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- add condition "ui -> pick instance with UID: uiSliderHandle.UID"
- size animation
- tilt effect
- color change
- sound effect

children.text: when this handle needs to update position (not necessarily being moved by player)

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- add condition "ui -> pick instance with UID: uiSliderHandle.UID"
- use a tween to perform the requirements below

required:
- set X to Functions.uiSliderHandleGetRealX(ui.ID)
- set Y to Functions.uiSliderHandleGetRealY(ui.ID)

children.text: this moves the fill to the start position, changing the actual position

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- add condition "ui -> pick instance with UID: uiSliderFill.UID"
- use a tween to perform the requirements below

required:
- set X to uiSliderFill.sliderFill_startPosX
- set Y to uiSliderFill.sliderFill_startPosY

children.text: this extends the fill towards the end position, changing the width / angle.

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- add condition "ui -> pick instance with UID: uiSliderFill.UID"
- use tweens to perform the requirements below

required:

- set Angle to 
angle(uiSliderFill.sliderFill_startPosX, uiSliderFill.sliderFill_startPosY,
uiSliderFill.sliderFill_endPosX, uiSliderFill.sliderFill_endPosY)

- set Width to 
distance(uiSliderFill.sliderFill_startPosX, uiSliderFill.sliderFill_startPosY,
uiSliderFill.sliderFill_endPosX, uiSliderFill.sliderFill_endPosY)

children.text: when content in a scroll view is being moved horizontally

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- add condition "ui -> pick instance with UID: uiScrollComponent.UID"
- use a tween to perform the requirements below
- make the tween ease soft, like Out Sinusoidal for example

required:
- set X to uiScrollComponent.scrollTargetX

children.text: when content in a scroll view is being moved vertically

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- add condition "ui -> pick instance with UID: uiScrollComponent.UID"
- use a tween to perform the requirements below
- make the tween ease soft, like Out Sinusoidal for example

required:
- set Y to uiScrollComponent.scrollTargetY

children.text: when a checkbox is selected (the value was changed)

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- add condition to pick ui family instance, then call the default uiSelect
- you can make it different than the normal button select too if you want, it's up to you!

children.text: when the checkbox is changed to true (it got 'checked')

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- create some sort of visual indicator that the checkbox was selected, this is also up to you how you want to do it! you could...

- create a checkmark sprite, make it a child of the checkbox, then set it visible here
- create a little bar sprite, make it a child of the checkbox, set it on the left side of the checkbox, then make it move to the right side here (to look like a switch)

children.text: when the checkbox is changed to false (it got 'unchecked')

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- do the opposite of what you did in uiCheckboxEnabled

children.title: ui / custom actions / carousel / all
children.description: these custom actions apply for all carousels, regardless of type

children.text: when entering carousel input mode meaning pressing left or right now only changes the value (doesn't happen with mouse)

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- pick ui family instance with UID
- call default uiSelect
- grow in size
- change color
- make a visual appear telling the player to press left and right

children.text: when exiting the carousel mode (doesn't happen with mouse)

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- do the opposite of what you did in uiCarouselSelect

children.text: when trying to increment the carousel, even though it's already at the farthest right value

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- let the player know there's no more values past this point
- flash red
- tilt
- size animation
- mesh points skew to the right
- error sound
- also acceptable to just do nothing here!

children.text: when trying to decrement the carousel, even though it's already at the farthest left value

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- let the player know there's no more values past this point
- flash red
- tilt
- size animation
- mesh points skew to the left
- error sound
- also acceptable to just do nothing here!

children.title: ui / custom actions / carousel / value
children.description: for value carousels only, which only display text

children.text: when increment (moving to the right)

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- move carousel to the right, then tween back to original spot
- make right arrow flash
- make right arrow disappear if at the end
- grow
- tilt
- make just the text tween by picking it as child

children.text: when decrement (moving to the left)

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- do what you did in uiCarouselIncrement, but for the left side

children.title: ui / custom actions / carousel / content
children.description: for content carousels which can display anything by creating a template - enable the bool on a uiCarousel to use this

children.text: when increment (moving to the right) but for content carousels

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- call uiCarouselIncrement, or make some different default animation

children.text: when decrement (moving to the left) but for content carousels

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- call uiCarouselDecrement, or make some different default animation

children.text: when the content anchor is created because the player incremented

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- make it fade in
- make it slide in from the right
- doing nothing is also acceptable

children.text: when the content anchor is created because the player decremented

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
recommendations:
- do what you did in uiCarouselContentCreatedIncrement but for the left side (if there's no difference you could just call the action directly)

children.text: when the content anchor is to be destroyed because the player incremented

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
required:
- destroy this object

recommendations:
- make it fade out, and set destroy on complete to true
- make it slide out to the left

children.text: when the content anchor is to be destroyed because the player decremented

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events

actions.text:
required:
- destroy this object

recommendations:
- do what you did in uiCarouselContentDestroyedIncrement but to the right side (if there's no difference you could just call it directly)

children.title: ui / behavior
children.description: the hardest to understand group in this entire framework, for sure. there are some things here that you will want to change, like the custom actions for UI components that define the default behavior of every component when certain events happen. there's also stuff to do with updates, selection, and navigation.

children.text: some functions here are marked with [INTERNAL], meaning that you shouldn't be using them when making your game unless it's for a specific case where you know what you're doing

children.title: ui / behavior / components
children.description: the inner-workings of components such as sliders, scroll views, and checkboxes. normally you shouldn't have to edit these, if you want to change animations check 'ui / behavior / custom actions'

children.text: not all components need additional internal programming, like checkboxes. only the ones that do can be found here.

children.title: ui / behavior / components / misc
children.description: stuff related to all components, essentials like the UID-to-ID conversion functions

children.text: given an ID, retrieve a UID

children.functionDescription: given an ID, retrieve a UID

functionParameters.name: ID
functionParameters.comment: id that you can find on the ui family

actions.text:
the reason this function is important is due to the family overlap that exists throughout this framework - almost all UI components exist in the 'ui' family, but some exist in other ui-related families.

of course, for example, you can't pick a 'uiSliderHandle' from a 'ui' id... but you can always pick it if you have the UID!

children.text: given a UID, retrieve an ID

children.functionDescription: given a UID, retrieve an ID

functionParameters.name: UID
functionParameters.comment: UID, object must be part of UI family

children.title: ui / behavior / components / slider
children.description: sliders are made up of various parts, and can double as scrollers in some cases. you'll find stuff related to sliders here.

children.title: ui / behavior / components / slider / fill
children.description: the fill isn't a necessary part of a slider and you can leave it out. it's a 9Patch that extends from one point to another, and looks pretty nice for sliders that convey a sense of completion or value

children.text: update the fill dimensions - make sure to set 9patch origin to 'left'

children.title: ui / behavior / components / slider / handle
children.description: this can get complicated, so just remember that the handle is different from the bar. you can only have one bar, but you can have multiple handles. as such, the value is stored in the handle itself and this is the part that can be navigated. also, slider handles can be designated as scroll handles, which can be used in a scroll view.

children.text: get the position of this handle, according to its value
these are more reliable than trying to get uiSliderHandle.X and .Y, since the position may be tweening

children.functionDescription: get the position of this handle, according to its value
get the position of this handle, according to its value

if greater rule handle exists, store greater value
modify this handle's value based on lesser and greater rules
don't get confused! this value must be LESS THAN the 'lesserValue' but GREATER THAN the 'greaterValue'!
if equal value isn't allowed, and values are equal, subtract a step
if equal value isn't allowed, and values are equal, add a step
final adjustments to this value

actions.text: calculate a number from 0 to 1, based on the slider value relative to the slider min/max

children.title: ui / behavior / updates
children.description: updates are when something changes in UI components, use function calls to iterate through all relevant items and change their visual state. you can call these manually in some cases, though generally it should just work fine.

children.text: run a general UI update (only affects navigable objects (not all components are navigable, like slider bars and fills))

if button was recently deactivated

ex: Function "slider mainSettingsMusicHandle", params: value

children.title: ui / behavior / navigate
children.description: everything to do with navigation, generally for directional inputs. navigation is proximity based, meaning the next button to choose is determined by distance and angle. selection-related events can be found here as well.

children.text: selects the currently chosen UI component

children.functionDescription: selects the currently chosen UI component

children.text: if this is a slider handle

actions.text: if you're looking for the string function call for sliders, you should look in 'ui / behavior / updates' instead

go back to normal navigation, and then call custom action, signifies handle being 'put down'

actions.text: similarly, the string function call is elsewhere; 'ui / behavior / components / carousel' instead

children.text: else, treat it as a button

actions.text:
will call a function with the syntax ("checkbox " & ui.ID) WITH one parameter, bool 'enabled'.

ex: Function "checkbox mainSettingsEnableBloom", params: 'enabled'

add this function to any event sheet to register when the checkbox is selected, and to get the state of uiChecked as a bool

children.text: custom actions specific to checkboxes
normal button

actions.text:
will call a function with the syntax ("select " & ui.ID) and no parameters

ex: Function "select mainPlay"

these groups are specifically to do with navigation, whether that be directional, or with a mouse.

else, perform the navigation

if components exist in this direction, pick the closest of them
if none found, wrap around to UI on the other side of the screen

children.title: ui / behavior / navigate / slider
children.description: controlled by uiSetNavigationMode, disabled on start on purpose

children.text:
the math here is very specific
we take the sin() or cos() of the angle of the slider bar
then we take the sign() of it, which provides either -1, 0, or 1
finally depending on if its an increment or decrement we make it negative or positive

this allows increments to work even with irregular slider bar angles
center slider handle if scrollable

children.title: ui / interaction
children.description: an interface from which the player can actually navigate and use the game UI. you can find keyboard, mouse, and gamepad controls here, with some variables you can adjust as you see fit.

children.text:
this is where the user actually uses inputs to be able to interact with the ui. 
once again I don't recommend messing with any of this stuff...

but, if you want to change how fast it scrolls when you hold a directional button, you could change the constant variables below.
on default, you need to hold down a button for 0.5 seconds, before it starts auto scrolling every 0.1 seconds
how long you need to hold down an input in order to start the auto-choosing behavior
how often the input repeats when auto-choosing
if ui input was triggered on this frame (make sure this variable is above the events, won't work otherwise)
how often the input repeats when using gamepad to scroll
gamepad deadzone for UI navigation
what fraction of a step does the gamepad scroll per timer fire

children.title: ui / interaction / kbm
children.description: keyboard AND mouse controls found here - note that this group does get disabled when switching to gamepad.

children.text: if gamepad is detected, switch to gamepad controls
switch input device

children.title: ui / interaction / kbm / mouse
children.description: the mouse controls for UI are fundamentally different from keyboard and gamepad, since it isn't directional. it's still a part of the 'kbm' group though since you can't use a mouse and a gamepad.

children.text: the reason carousel isn't present here is because mouse controls work differently for them. when you click a carousel, you don't enter a new navigation mode, you just increment or decrement it based on which side of the object you clicked. as a result, you can find carousel selection in the default group

children.title: ui / interaction / kbm / mouse / default
children.description: controlled by the uiSetNavigationMode function

children.text: mouseover choosing
if the while loop completes and it appears the mouse is not over anything, pass will be false

if not over any ui components that are active
returns 1 if mouse is over UI, and also registers changes

children.functionDescription: returns 1 if mouse is over UI, and also registers changes

children.text: make sure this isn't a scrollview component that's off its mask
choose this component, but only if it's not already chosen
if set to center on mouseover, call the centering function
run a generic update
left click to select option

actions.text: below you can find normal button selection, as well as an exception for carousels

children.text: if carousel
basically takes mouse position and rotates it relative to the carousel angle
increment
decrement
else just normal select

children.title: ui / interaction / kbm / mouse / slider
children.description: controlled by the uiSetNavigationMode function, is disabled on start on purpose.

slider drag

actions.text: basically takes mouse position and rotates it relative to the slider bar angle
calculate slider value using mUnlerped and slider bar range
update

mouse scrolling
if shift is down, invert mouse wheel controls
apply mouse wheel effects to scroller handles
arrow key navigation

children.title: ui / interaction / gamepad
children.description: gamepad related controls. keep in mind that only gamepad 0 can navigate the UI. also, this group is disabled manually on purpose, by the assumption that most players would start with keyboard and mouse.

children.text: if kbm is detected, switch to kbm controls
directional navigation using d-pad and left stick
select with enter
scroll using right stick
wait for scroll timer to bypass duration
set x axis scroller
set y axis scroller
arrow key auto choosing timer

children.functionDescription: when player presses a directional input (keyboard or gamepad)

children.text: if the held duration is at 0 (activate immediately on input), otherwise operate on auto timer
check if a ui input has been registered on this frame
held down timer
auto scroll timer

actions.text: reset both timers to 0 when no inputs are being pressed
